YECeHXD6l-hVSA29iTDayw.text: Excellent spot for some delicious meats. LEGITIMATE waygu beef is served here. Beautiful restaurant and great ambiance.   Server extremely knowledgeable. But, i must warn everyone, if you are on a budget, steer clear of this place. For me, it was well worth the cost. From the caviar, to the wine, to the cotton candy wrapped foie gras, it was an amazing meal.

XUdBsy51fY-gvnw8abh1pw.text: I made the reservation for Ferran Adria's olives, and they were, as expected, interesting (in a good way). What was completely unexpected was how fantastic everything else was.   The lamb chops and the ribeye tasting were cooked to perfection. The croquetas de jamon are the best things I've ever put in my mouth. The Vanilla Ice Cream Experience was fun and fascinating.   Service was impeccable. We never wanted for anything and our waiter seemed genuinely excited that we were having such a great time. Everyone was friendly and helpful.   The wine list was extensive and had interesting choices. My merlot blend (by the glass) had a complex flavor profile that I enjoyed to the last sip.   The kitchen is open and it's very easy to see all of the dishes coming out. Watching people at their various stations turn out beautiful food was so fun.  It was fancy, but approachable without any pretentiousness. A perfect night.

sOmrLutVJPMhPqy1u0--hQ.text: Stopped by for a solo dinner at their bar and was greeted by a very friendly set of bartenders. They immediately recommended I try the cotton candy mojito which was delicious. After that I had their Salt Air Mojito, which was topped with a salty foam. Since most of the menu is tapas style I was able to try a few things without over-stuffing myself. The bartender, this turkish guy, was super friendly and made eating solo a bit more memorable.  Suckling Pig Sandwich - A mini sandwich that was very flavorful and filled with delicious pork  Foie Gras Cotton Candy - As sweet and decadent as it sounds. Even if you normally don't eat Foie, this is worth a try!

hXVMgxbfLTcc2oJmOAMFmA.text: The good:  great service; amazing choice of meats; wide range of choices on the menu. The bad:  very noisy and busy, it was not a relaxing dinner,  lots of servers moving around fast - stressful.  We had the tenderloin and we were far from being wowed by it, it was not tender, it was chewy,  and frankly tasteless. The tenderloin came with a sauce on the side that was cold. We think it was supposed to be warm. Didn't really care for it. The butter mashed potatoes were really good. Overall we would not recommend it.

ZcVenfXtOXOhiRXeCXBv3w.text: So here's the low down. This is one of those restaurants either you hate the concept or you embrace and love the concept. The preparation and presentation is pretty bazaar as in its restaurant name. This place is also known for their tapas, but Believe Me, they are Really small plates at a hefty price.  So if you're not impressed by the presentation, by the small portion size, and by the price you'll be disappointed because the food is pretty standard.  As for myself I've given this place a couple tries. The first time around we tried a little bit of everything based on the server's recommendation. We had the endive salad, king crab & shrimp cocktail, vittore carpaccio, live scallops, gazpacho shots (compliments of the chef), jamon croquettes, the magic mojito (gimmicky melt the cotton candy type of drink), and a couple of desserts. I didn't understand what the high ratings were about?! After all, I did come here based on the yelp reviews and I was a bit disappointed with my experience. Every dish was mediocre, but eventually decided to give it another try....  Second time around I figured maybe we should try the steak since we didn't try it the first time. So we went with the Rosewood, TX wagyu (over 2lbs, bone is included in the weight, $75/lb), button mushrooms, scallops, delmonico potatoes, a couple wines, chicken croquettes, & don't be lemon drink which was served table side with dry ice.  I was really hoping to enjoy this time around given that we were trying out different dishes, but my experience was still the same as the first. One thing I truly enjoyed were the button mushrooms. Super juicy & rich in flavor! As for the steak it was over seasoned making it way too salty, but it was cooked to a perfect medium rare with a nice char on the outside.   Each time, we've spent $300+ and have walked out with our tummies feeling unsatisfied.   Besides the food I do commend the fabulous service they have here.

sZp4-Wo7x4E5ZCHalnDLtg.text: Bazaar Meat is an outstanding restaurant with a creative menu and impeccable service.  It is a mecca for foodies and "armchair gourmets" such as myself.  They will also happily accommodate a tasting menu for a table of one, unlike some restaurants (such as the arrogant Wing Lei at Wynn) that will not.  My only suggestion is that if you are interested in going, do so sooner than later.  I was there on a Tuesday night and the restaurant was packed (a good sign).  But the SLS hotel was a ghost town.  Maybe the hotel picks up a bit on weekends, but word on the street is that it is struggling to maintain services and may soon be facing new ownership or closure.  If so, could Bazaar Meat survive at a new location?  Perhaps.  But why chance it?  Go now and enjoy!

343f70-VXpSjP3jX1hA0qg.text: Terrible Service would be an understatement, my wife and I were sat down and Our waiter greeted us and explained the menu and got us super excited for what we were about to experience, shortly after, a party of approximately 12 people were sat next to us and then we never saw our waiter again.  No drink or appetizer order was taken as We sat patiently for 20 minutes and then just became irritated as the party next to us received drinks and their appetizer after appetizer were brought to the table.  Look we get it the big party was his paycheck for the evening but, This was a special trip for us as we were celebrating a promotion for my wife.  This is Not the Service you would expect from a dining experience that is a minimum of $200 a person.  This was very disappointing to say the least as this was not the start we had in mind to our night.  The manager Pano did try to make it right when we got up and walked out and asked if he could reseat us somewhere, but we felt it would be too hard to enjoy ourselves after what we just experienced.  What a bummer as eating at an establishment such as this is not something we do all the time and This is something we plan for and for it to end like it did was just not how we envisioned our experience.  ****Since this review Pano the manager has reached out to us and was very apologetic and offered us to come back.  He is very professional and courteous individual and really wants his guest to have an experience they will never forget.  Hopefully someday we will be back in town to get give it another try.

7_y9URPL6HwNzjk4iPKP_w.text: I loved this place! The steak was amazing snd the unique dishes were great, I loved seeing the meat out. The ambiance is a little old school but food was amazing and was the highlight of my Vegas trip. My sweetheart impressed me!

d6RuKbTwJ1B-XoT_nLrWcg.text: Dinner... Nice place secluded in the lobby area...Nice atmosphere, great music, great service.... a lot of unique spins on food.. definite return visit needed!  6/7/17 Changing my review to 5 star... because of the follow up by Christopher Bugeya the manager on my yelp review.  This is a restaurant that really cares about how customers feel about their service and food!  Well done!

DGPwZAOUUhEAvxn8JaiWXQ.text: What a fantastic experience!! The food, the service, the experience exceeded all expectations. From the start my group was entertained with table side cocktails that only started an amazing night filled with fantastic food and drinks. Needless to say, would certainly recommend dining at Bazaar, you will not be disappointed.

vDwPvINgpQPCyhs-IISs_w.text: Disappointed  I really wanted to like this place and came with great anticipation.  I had eaten the Vaca Vieja (old cow) in Barcelona and it was an absinthe experience. So I was expecting similar here at Bazaar.  But the steak tasted like a normal steak. Nice enough but not as drastically different as eating wagyu or Vaca Vieja which are both profoundly different  Dessert options are very limited and underwhelming for a high end place

Qr2K047sSvcNP5CLdbszSg.text: Came here for dinner on a Monday night. Luckily it wasn't very crowded and we were seated within 30 minutes without reservations.   I'm not going to go over every dish, because there are a lot, but everything was incredibly tasty. The meats, the seafood, the veggies and the drinks all hit the spot. Even though we were pretty adventurous, even ordering dishes with ingredients that I'd usually avoid, not a single dish missed the mark.   Obviously this place is pricey, so as long as you go in ready to spend, it's definitely worth it.

bmp7eH4gGlxLV-OonOYLHg.text: The food at Bazaar Meat is 5 stars, easily one of the best meals I've ever had but the service was pretty lack luster so I couldn't give Bazaar Meat 5 stars.  Came in for a birthday dinner on 9/7 with a party of 8 and we feasted hard. I think we had about half the menu, our server was told a price point and the food that was delivered did not disappoint.  At first there was confusion about one of the members of our party. Our server thought he was vegetarian but he just didn't want steak. So a few too many vegetarian items were sent out as filler which we ate but it was a tad overboard.   Pre-bussing was pretty scarce throughout the meal, plates were only cleared when the next course was being presented and even then many plates were left on the table throughout service.   Our server pushed the house favorite steak from Rosewood ranch I believe. For a $60+ per pound steak it had good flavor but was still pretty tough for being medium rare and we did not enjoy it. Wait staff was made aware that we didn't like the steak but a manager never did a table touch to address the concern.   The other steak we ordered which I can't pronounce but it's about $90 a pound was delicious and the table devoured it.  Our server had other tables so we knew he was kind of busy but the lack of attention to a table that's spending over $250 per person was kind of a let down. With an automatic 20% grat I guess he figured he didn't have to try too hard.  After an amazing dessert presentation for the birthday boy we sat around for a bit and passed around presents. The waiter didn't stop by or check on us after that for near an hour till we could finally flag him down to close out.  It really left a bad taste in everyone's mouth after a great meal.    We were at bazaar meats for 4 hours when it really should have been 3. The wait still need to learn to ask for help if they are overwhelmed so that the guest experience doesn't suffer.

7gL9xOONdS5n-LJRuKdqPg.text: 2019 Vegas. Dinner review.  4 - Cotton Candy Foie Gras (Crispy amaranth)  3 - THE Foieffle (Air waffles, foie espuma, peanut butter, honey)  5 - Kobe Air Bread  4 - "Vaca Vieja"Ribeye Tasting  5 - Suckling Lamb Hind Leg  Overall, "as good as it gets."

CHjVhUm9juSYYJ5-oIp4xQ.text: Lol, this place for sure has some Bizarre meats! And I mean that in the best way possible.  I got to say, I was not sure what to think. I am more of a fish gal however my husband is a red meat loving man and literally talked about going here for weeks before we got to Vegas. This is one of the only restaurants that has True wagyu Kobe beef. Which is from the Kobe region of Japan and cuts like butter.   Our server was super awesome, he took my husband all around and let him hand pick his own steaks. He also brought us a little tray of cured meats to try. This really made our experience special because we wanted to try everything!!! It was obvious he could tell how excited my husband was. Which I thought was sweet and meant a lot to us.   I of course, (being a fish lover) ordered the Turbot, I didn't realize how big this fish was which was maybe my fault. I only ate about 1/5 of my meal which had me feeling V sad to let it go to waste. He told me it was a whole fish, but I didn't know how big we were talking. A Turbot is an odd looking fish but it cooks very well and taste amazing.  Just don't google pics they are not cute they are bizarre for sure.  My Husband tried 4, 1oz pieces of wagyu and ordered an entire 2LB bone in steak. He ate every single bite.  We also got the cotton candy foie gras which is out standing and you do need to eat it all in one bite.  We had a stellar dining experience here which was all made amazing due to our server, he really took great care of us and make us feel special. We would like to be his friend. Lol!!!   Anyways, if you go, do your research prior to, it's a big menu and it's not cheap so know what you want to invest in and ask about portion size. So you can enjoy every single bite.

photos.caption: Photo of Bazaar Meat by José Andrés - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Turbot
Photo of Bazaar Meat by José Andrés - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Cotton Candy Foie Gras

7fLknx2HaSqwrbeJoZT2Ng.text: Cotton candy and duck? Bazaar meat is much more than just a swanky steakhouse, it has the whimsical personality and character of Jose that really shines through in the menu. For starters, we DID the cotton candy fois gras. Yes, you heard that correctly. It's a mini cotton candy stick with a fois gras center that is both sweet and savory...you just have to try it!   We were also treated to complementary chicken croquettes served in a glass dish shaped like a shoe. Why a shoe? Because young Jose used to get yelled at by his mother for putting his feet up on the kitchen table while waiting for his food, so he thought it would be funny to serve his mother's recipe in a literal shoe. It's these kinds of small touches that add personality to what would otherwise be just another expensive steakhouse.   On to the main course: THE MEAT!! I got the skirt steak, 8oz so a pretty good size, with a rosemary mustard sauce. The steak was cooked to perfection and delicious, especially with the sauce! I also got asparagus with Romesco sauce as a side and it was the perfect accompaniment.   If I were to go back I would definitely try the s'mores sandwich (featuring, you guessed it, fois gras). What is this guy's obsession with duck? Although pricey it was a great experience and, if you visit Vegas and you're craving a great steakhouse please try it!

Photo of Bazaar Meat by José Andrés - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Skirt steak with rosemary mustard sauce

DahyPoLoFBtaYXL3dvpEFw.text: I was so excited to finally try this place! We started with a Caesar salad. The waiter did not warn us that this wasn't a regular salad. Instead of what you're used to, they bring out Caesar salad sliders in a way. They are bite size pieces of lettuce with the salad toppings on them. They had a very strong taste and I didn't eat more than one bite.   The picture I posted of the fried food in a shoe was brought to us by the waiter because there were two other items we ordered that we didn't like and he said he felt bad. I absolutely hate wasting things but they just were not good. However, the item in the shoe (a potato I think) was alright but I wouldn't order it.   The steak and potatoes were delicious! The filet comes sliced and was super tender. The potatoes were creamy and there's enough to share. The waiter explained that the steak would take some time but it ended up taking 90 minutes to get our dinner. I eat at nice steak houses almost weekly and that's outrageous!  The dessert cart was super cute but after how long it took for dinner, I was ready to leave so we skipped dessert.

CBprC6TieeWEGbr6DBHMsw.text: This is the ideal place to take your husband or boyfriend for a night out he will never forget. As the name suggests, it is ALL about the meat here! The quality can't be surpassed, the service and attention to detail is worth every penny. We really enjoyed our meals, everything was perfect, from timing to presentation. Highly recommended!

photos.caption: Photo of Bazaar Meat by José Andrés - Las Vegas, NV, United States

qgsoaCVrVwiALMJfJNye9w.text: Bazaar isn't your typical steakhouse. The new age concept seemed innocent enough when taking the in-laws to dine. Thinking it'd be a better alternative than a la carte, we ordered the tasting menu. The big drawback to this option was that it took Almost 3 hours to eat and there was some waiting in between the courses. It would have been nice to be forewarned on the time, but it was also a weekend evening. The menu did provide a good survey of many dishes on the menu, and the waiters always eloquently introduced each course. The decor and drinks are swanky, but also inter-spliced  with game heads and Mardi Gras beads on the wall. Interesting approach! Try Bazaar if you don't mind a new age approach to the average steakhouse. Don't go expecting a typical Old school style wine and dine steakhouse.

obkDOpx5TEtoBG-t6vjuEg.text: I've dined here a few times over the years and I've seen a lot of great tapas! The ambiance here is exactly what we need for a night out. Whether you're on a date night or you're here for a business meeting, the restaurant has an amazing layout to accomodate people of all backgrounds. They have an open kitchen where you can see the fresh meats and the staff working hard pumping tapas out one after another.  Known for fine dining, Jose Andres has a reputation to uphold. These tapas are some of the best tapas you'll ever have. For starters, there is nothing I love more than their Kobe airbread. It's very light. When you take a bite, you'll notice the bread deflates and the cream filling comes out. They are $12 a piece. Each piece will get you around 2-3 bites. We also really enjoy their cotton candy foie gras, Jose's tacos, the deli meat platter, and the beef tartar. They serve their tartar here with rolls. The other locations serve with a crunchy cone and I prefer that. However people definitely come here for their steaks. They do live up to their name. They have so many cuts of steaks and can tell you how long they have been aged for. Their meats are of high quality and are very expensive.   Service here is my other favorite reason to dine here. They have amazing food but the service is just as spectacular. I can always find someone cleaning a plate for us, providing us with a refill, or asking us if there's something we need. Every time we've dined here, we've spoken to the manager. The manager makes his / her way around to all the tables to greet the guest. On our last visit, someone dropped off our tapa and didn't want to interrupt the conversation the manager was having with us. The manager made the individual come back to our table to introduce the tapa. They do a great job explaining each dish as they come. It's part of the experience.

Photo of Bazaar Meat by José Andrés - Las Vegas, NV, United States

39cESu6Z0QroZDz1K1w7fw.text: Stayed at the SLS on a group outing back in June. During a discussion of which steakhouses we should check out a few kept coming back to the idea of trying something "in-house." My friend Jaysen T. did research on Bazaar and kept the idea alive. Frankly I thought the guys lazy but when you are on vacation with guys wanting to spend monies on gambling rather than food... Just go where ever I guess.  The final headcount for dinner on a Monday evening was for two and between us we spent about $150 - $180 each.   Food. The memorable part of dinner was the cotton candy foie gras which I could have had seconds of. My buddy was weirded out by the concept but he's also not the type to try foie gras generally.  Many of the plates are portioned and cut to allow for easy grabbing/ sharing.   I'll save you from the play by play of shared starters, plates and selections of meat. Based on our ideas and those shared by the waiter, we ordered plenty for sharing. But final thoughts were that we could have gone elsewhere and had something tastier. Dinner was a let down. I don't mind shelling out some cash for a good meal. This did not satisfy.  The presentation and setup of the restaurant draws attention to the kitchen and grilling areas. If guests were to pick up their meats from the presentation area, that would really be something. Only a few moments are spent when entering and passing that area. To be able to view your cut of meat/meal cooked and plated... ie chef's table experience would be something. However, the flavors have to backup the associated costs..

DVHVkTMLFmnLXYt1AA2fFg.text: So this place is in the old Sahara resort.  You better love meat when you come me here and if you do you will be greatly rewarded.   We started at the bar as we waited for our table.  Great drink options with unique cocktails.  I got a whiskey cocktail.  It was smoked and had great flavors.  It was not a long wait till we were seated.  The place was packed but I did not feel we were on top of the people next to us even though we did have conversations with those on either side.  Our server was prompt and offered good suggested for feasting.    We got the $125 tasting menu that had a bit of everything. I have to admit I thought it was really slow getting our food but when we did it was really good.    The brought us The Super-Giant Pork-Skin Chicharron broken up table side.  I guess this was like a bread service.  We had so much of this left.    Then we had oysters that had a sea foam topping. They were very creative and very tasty.  Also the Ferran Adria Olives, Modern & Traditional Liquid green olive, gordal olives stuffed with piquillo pepper and anchovy was something very unique.  A liquefied olive with the normal stuffing.   We moved on to have multiple items, , Bison Buffalo style, Lucia's Salad with Endive Caesar salad, Parmesan, anchovy, air croutons, Bagels & Lox Cone with Dill cream cheese, salmon roe, Croquetas de Pollo made with Chicken-bechamel fritters.    The meat course was a Chateaubriand. Tenderloin Brandt Beef, CA, Holstein, Perigord sauce, pomme souffle.  Of course it was perfectly cooked and melted in your mouth.  potatoes and asparagus as sides were perfect.    Our final experience was a dessert of Cream puffs, assorted tarts, little cakes.  A nice finish.    We had wine throughout the meal with a pairing at each serving.  We shared it to help keep money in our pockets and not get to drunk.  .     It was a great experience in food eating.  So many interesting foods and takes on familiar things.  Be prepared to spend a lot of money, over $300 if you follow what we did but consider it a dinner and a show as each course was like a new act in the Jose Andres show!!

CrYojg2c3ajO1dMi0_casw.text: This is my first experience at this restaurant and it was not what I expected.  I'm only giving 1 star because the waiter named can was very nice. Firstly, I came here with my girlfriend to spend our anniversary in Vegas. The appetizers were good and the garlic mashed potatoes were very delicious. When my steak came out which I've ordered the ribeye taster; It was not a ribeye and I know my meats. It was a strip loin and it was really tough. I would rather go to another steak house restaurant who has better quality meat. Money isn't an issue but I would like the quality of meat that I pay for to be up to par. I will definitely not be coming here again with the quality of meat that came out on my dinner plate. I hope everyone else who reads this has a better experience than what we had. It was very disappointing also they dont have any special desserts for certain occasions.

EO0yNtrGhGkCIcLn91cKJw.text: This is an old draft that I forgot to post from 2017... I went again in 2019 and still love it (although the meat was a little fattier this visit).  Love, love, love! Am a huge fan of Jose Andres and was happy to head out to SLS to try it! Great atmosphere, not a romantic restaurant, and set up for parties of all sizes. Good spacing and love the open grills and meat displays as you enter.  It's pricey so bring your wallet. Food and service were all top notch. Creative cotton candy type cocktails too! We did a mix of 3 starters, 2 meats and a side and were stuffed. Had to skip dessert. Absolutely loved the jamon croquetas - have not had anything better since leaving Spain! The Ferran Adria olives (copy of the El Bulli/Tickets one) were a disappointment if you've had the real thing. Would not order them again - not bad, just not that spectacular. The sloppy joes were tasty with the crispy topping - different twist on a casual dish. Would skip this next time.  Loved our meats! The choices are somewhat overwhelming! The sausage with the pain con tomate is classic Spain. Loved this. The rib eye was more American but well flavoured and it's nice to sample a variety of meat here. The garlic mushrooms were a perfect side.  One of my favorite Vegas meals... and we come here annually! Will be back!

photos.caption: Photo of Bazaar Meat by José Andrés - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Awesome salad with some type of lemony foam. This was delicious!
Photo of Bazaar Meat by José Andrés - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Sloppy joes
Photo of Bazaar Meat by José Andrés - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Get this! Jamon croquetas - amazing!

nTsQ0izTHwxG-mz3wBb9xQ.text: This place is AMAZEBALLS. If you're a carnivore like I am you MUST come here. Oddly placed inside SLS, this restaurant like all Jose Andres restaurants offers the quality and memorable meal you'd request for your last meal!  We came here for my birthday and trusted our server to create a personalized tasting menu for us that was nothing short of perfect.  Some memorable items (my mouth is watering as I type this):  Chef's selection of 6 cured meats - my favorite was the 4-year cured Jamon Iberico Foie Gras wrapped in fresh cotton candy Suckling pig Grilled Pulpo  Beef Carpaccio (maybe my favorite of the night!) - Washugyu beef, espuma and the best whipped parmesan puree you'll ever have Rosewood wagyu ribeye steak Jose's Asian Tacos - jamon iberico de bellota, toasted nori seaweed, flying fish roe  Yum. I can't wait to go back!

AgOoJ9BNXG5Vv2hhSGAb0A.text: I guess I don't understand the hype. Maybe a biased reviewer as I love meat but don't think steak is that great. Idk! I feel like even if you cook steak well, the taste just cant go above and beyond  Overall, good, don't hate that I came here, but I'm not itching to come back. If I factor in the high prices, I probably wouldn't recommend this place and be sad I came lol  1.Octopus - really good! came with a really tangy tomato-y vinaigrette that was almost too acidic, but I really enjoyed it. Octopus was cooked to perfection - it was charred but super tender. Some friends thought it was too charred but I didnt mind it 2. Chicken croquettes - compliments of the chef. Think a warm chicken salad (with shredded chicken) shaped like a mozarella stick and also fried like a mozarella stick. Good, but nothing I would pay for at a pricey restaurant 3. Wagyu / black angus steak from TX. Got 2 pounds for three people. We thought this was a decent amount of meat which was cooked to perfection. It's lightly seasoned, and comes with a small side bowl of nice salt so everyone can season it to taste. There were some fatty pieces, but overall a great steak   Good, attentive service - what you'd expect for a place like this and for the prices you're paying. Though I do think this high prices do reflect high quality meat as well as the celebrity chef name

P4mS_aCjQJCJ9xVNtqSVDQ.text: The best meal I've ever eaten in my life.  Chris the GM was amazing, walked us through the dishes and picked the most amazing food we've ever eaten.  7 dudes, who have eaten steak all their life, EACH said it was their #1 meal of their life.  Combined we have eaten at some of the best restaurants on the planet .  That said, THIS was the best restaurant, I don't care what anyone says, they are wrong if they say different   Recommendation, ask Chris what to order for you, don't order for yourself.  Thank me

nWS_PZoXE4N9Qf1eagUq-g.text: Just wow! It's a bit far from the strip so be warned! I was super excited to try this place! I've heard so many reviews and rave about it. The place is an art piece itself! Right when you enter the restaurant you are welcome with the smell of grilled meat and a whole display of all their cuts of meats. The hostess was a sweet young lady who made us felt very welcome. We sat closer towards the bathroom so got to walk through the whole restaurant. I love the modern and sleek look of the place.   We order the chicharron and wasn't too satisfied with the dips it arrived with. I would have just loved some salsa or Tajin seasoning. The dip was a very bland, tart whipped Greek yogurt of some sort. It was lacking of flavor and the chicharron didn't have much seasoning to it either. The portion was huge though! We also ordered my fav Jose's take on the philly sandwich. I can eat ten of those mini sandwiches! We end up ordering their washugyu ribeye and it did not disappoint at all! It was aged and cooked perfectly! I'm not really a big steak gal, but my first bite left me wanting more. It was an explosion of juicy meaty flavor. I loved every bite of it! We also order the desserts, but I would recommend skipping on it. It was pricey for bite size portions and none really left me wanting more.

BwdSWc12msH4AdC3yAQaXA.text: We went last night as a group of 6.   I once heard of someone's "rules for life" was to always order an extra item at dinner, to open your mind to things that might surprise or disgust you. This is the place for an open mind. And we were surprised at how beautifully palatable everything was.  Must haves: - Jose's gin special drink was like Christmas in August. Smooth and balanced  - Cotton candy foie gras. Don't worry about what it is, it is an experience you won't regret - Purees potatoes were like spoonfuls of cream and butter - Sloppy joes. Ok these were my favorite. Bougiefied and delicious.  - I much rather preferred the lamb over steak   Bon appetit!

photos.caption: Photo of Bazaar Meat by José Andrés - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Jose gin special

zLYCgs47DrDDoOawVjp1bQ.text: This was an amazing experience.  The first item was my favorite because it was the most unexpected pleasant surprise.  Foie gras and cotton candy.  First you think that's just crazy... It's just for shock value... That can't work.  Well it's does. At the center is buttery rich foie gras wrapped in a simple cloud of cotton candy. Once you put it in your mouth the cotton candy melts forming a crispy layer over the foie gras and takes on this amazing roasted flavor. It's like a magic trick you want to try to figure out because it's so good. This absolutely blew my mind.  The experience was centered around the food but we were guided through the gastro journey with background stories of the chef or the food. The service was wonderful but the stories linked our experiences to the amazing flavors and textures we were partaking in.    Wow. Will want to find something similar back home.  A treat for very special occasions.

VmtqOJDiM5VzAa8HAiHM9Q.text: We came with friends to celebrate my wife's b'day. We really wanted to like Bazaar Meat, mainly because we are fans of Jose Andres. The restaurant is located in the far corner of the casino, away from the parking. Immediately on walking in, you are struck by the beautiful cuts of meat in the display case. Then the huge open grills with the meats cooking (lots of heat and great aromas). Very elegant ambiance despite the lack of table cloths. Michael, our server, was at our table immediately after we were seated. Very welcoming and super helpful in deciding what to order. We decided on 4 apps, 2 meats, and one side. We started with Jose's Asian Tacos ($16). Five small rectangles of seaweed topped with a very very thinly sliced piece of Iberian ham and some fish roe. The flavor of the seaweed overwhelmed the ham and fish roe. enjoyable but not special. The Pulpo Gallega ($22) is grilled octopus slices with small grilled potatoes in a light pimento sauce. It is a small plate but easily shared by the four of us. delish! Next came the Sloppy Joe ($12). While the menu stated it was on a steamed bun, it tasted fried. Stuffed with beef boldness and topped with a small amount of fried straw potatoes. Easily shared and very tasty. The last app was the Cotton Candy Foie Gras ($8). Very impressive presentation but I didn't taste it (really not easily shared). For our entrees, we got the Wagyu Black Angus from Rosewood Texas ($78/lb) and the Chateaubriand ($75/lb). The Wagyu is presented sliced with the bone on the side. I found it much too fatty to be enjoyable but my wife enjoyed it. The Chateaubriand  was also served sliced with a Perigord sauce on the side. This was tender and flavorful. With impressive ambiance and excellent service, why only 3 stars? The food should be knock your socks off quality in a restaurant of this level. While the apps were really special, the entrees were just good, but not special. I'm glad I tried it but I won't be returning.

1jIKkbCYR_ftLIA93l-fhg.text: First and foremost I just want to say we only sat at the bar for appetizers and drinks. I will update my review for when we actually have a sit down dinner here.   I was slightly disappointed that this wasn't the same Bazaar concept as the one in Beverly Hills, CA. BUT Jose Andres can do no wrong in my eyes. The bar is absolutely beautiful very tall ceilings and huge! this bar could probably sit up to 50 people I'd say. Nicole was our bartender and boy was she a character. Very funny and sweet. I started out with a Pisco Sour (my favorite cocktail) and it was pretty damn good. Its so hard to find a bartender that can make a great Pisco Sour. Andy had a scotch drink but i cannot remember what it was called.  We had a dozen oysters to start, wow they were amazing. we loved how small they were. It seems the smaller the oyster the more fresh they taste. Then we moved on to the Sloppy Joe sandwich. This was truly tasty, beef bolognese, fried straw potatoes, on a steamed bun. Cant go wrong with that!  We finished our little snack with a few Tahitian Vanilla cream puffs. I will seriously come back for those. Amazing.   All in all we had a great experience here and will be back for an actual dinner.

LMfZmoweoYeFZd6tQ9AocQ.text: Do not be mistaken. This is not a steak house. This is a carnivores' den. Everything is mismatched, disorganized, chaotic and oh-so-beautiful. Bazaar does an elegant spin on disheveled and it works. The chairs don't match, the tables are all different in one area to the next, the chandeliers aren't the same. But that's the fun of dining here. We had a double birthday for 7 people were seated at the "game of thrones" table. Medieval iron chandelier, colossal chairs and mounted game heads on the walls. Upon arrival, take note to visit the 4 open kitchens! The meat cabinet is the most interesting. The seafood kitchen is in the back room.   To suit the theme we ordered the quarter roast suckling pig (you can get a whole suckling pig too) which you can see hung in the glass display out front. This item is a must have since it made our steak take a back seat. There isn't anywhere that can do pig this tender and juicy. Mash potatoes were excellent to pair, which heirloom tomato salad which were very fresh. The one bite cotton candy foie gras is an experience on it's own. Creamy foie gras which the smooth texture blended is wrapped with a sweet grainy cotton candy. Just genius. Chicken croquettes were sent to the table compliments of the house which were a nice crispy kick to the meal as well. Would order on our own the next time. To complete, there was plentiful dessert (I had the chocolate matcha tea which was excellent) and smiles all around.  The whole experience tied together by excellent service who had the utmost patience for our wild and loud personalities and love from the very kind GM Yassine who did a fine job of making us feel very welcome. 6 stars if it were possible.

BZsWpYKyeE8zluRveMtNuw.text: Great experience and great food! It's on the pricey end so the food was up to par. I wasn't a big fan of their serving style and plating arrangements. We ordered two meats - rib eye and the suckling pig. Both were served on tall platters. It made it a little awkward not being able to see the person across the table. We kept ducking and giraffe necking to have conversations lol.   Anyways, for appetizers, we got the dozen oysters, charcuterie plate with bread, and sea urchin. The sea urchin is a must! I've never had sea urchin that good!! My mouth is watering just thinking about it again.  Our main course included the Rib steak (washugyu/angus). We ordered 2lbs, which included the bone, so as you can imagine... there wasn't very much meat. It came out pre-sliced but it was a little cold. Not very much flavor but still good. We also ordered the 1/4 suckling pig. It was amazing! Super crispy but fatty on the inside. I couldn't eat more than one piece though.   For sides, I can't remember exactly what they were but there was an apple/salad plate, potato dish, and a brussels sprout dish. They were all pretty tasty and helped balance out all the meat.  For dessert, we got an assortment of truffles, candy, creme puffs. Refer to the picture, can't remember what each of them were. I was a big fan of the hazelnut one. Tasted like a Ferrero Rocher creme puff!  Oh and can't forget the cocktails! First one I had was the cotton candy mojito! It was good but a little too sweet for me. The second was a hit! New York Sour! Get it!!!

ZizPGhNZ5u3Cf24WruJkeg.text: If you are in Las Vegas, I highly recommend going to Bazaar Meats. Everything we tried was amazing.   My personal favorites were: Grilled Octopus Succulent Pig Sandwich  Cotton Candy Foie Gras  Make sure you stop in at least once and try this marvelous restaurant.

The waiter over sold and was pushy and all the food is family style so it's hard to order if you have a sensitive palate. the brussels sprouts were yummy but everything else was basic and not worth the high price!

z8gyYzjoIHBoniwWSRkZVQ.text: No one on earth was waiting for this restaurant to open more than me. I was a regular at The Bazaar in Los Angeles. They treated me like a queen. They also treated everyone else like that, but who cares, because ME! I only went in for a tasty snack because I was alone and it's been a year and a half since I've been to the restaurant - I could wait no longer. The staff is so nice and accommodating that they would probably help you move to a new home. It feels like a thousand tiny hugs. My snacks were magical and there are a thousand new menu items that I can not wait to try- as this is a different concept restaurant.  I love this restaurant. I would marry it if it were socially acceptable.

qolLJaDiAWkthZMdK6cO5Q.text: Went with the wife for an anniversary dinner.  The wife got the GIn and tonic and it may of blew her panties off.  I don't drink so i just got a soda.  For Dinner I had Joses Way tasting menu.  The wife ordered a couple apps that we also wanted to try as well as her dinner.  Pretty much tasted the entire menu. I have heard a lot about the Cotton candy Foie but it didn't do it for me.  The show stopper for me was definitely the Smoke & ice oysters.  The steak was also absolutely perfect.  Enjoyed the carpaccio sticks as well.  Skip the giant pork skin unless you are sharing with a bigger table.  It can be too much.

IiUPE3R9Gd1yJ48VOeHmZg.text: We stayed at SLS Hotel for a weekend, and I was debating if I should get an evening cocktail either here at the Bazaar or some other bar that could potentially be cheaper! My experience with LA Bazaar is - its absolutely fantastic, but its also $$$. I was pleasantly surprised with how reasonable the bar menu prices were. There were 5 to 7pm special drink menu all at $8 including red and white wine. The cocktail I ordered was their Cotton Candy Magic Mojito. It was amazingly delicious. I spent I think about $16 on this cocktail, and every drop of it was so worth it! Just a day ago, I spent my money at Libertine Social at Mandalay Bay and I wasn't super impressed, but this place won me over! I also got to try the liquid nitrogen based LN2 dont be a lemon drink ($10). and I ordered a cotton candy foie gras, which I remembered from my trip to LA Bazaar! $8 - it was as divine as I remembered! I do want to come back for a full on dinner in teh future! so even if you arent staying at SLS make Bazaar bar - your stop! no reservation needed at the bar area!

YX_gSqYINeyywZllxhNgHw.text: Yum!  Came here for Christmas Eve dinner with my family and was definitely not disappointed. We had to push our original 7:00 reservation to 8:00 and then to 9:00 due to traffic coming from LA, which they were completely accommodating of. When we arrived, they were running about half an hour behind (they seemed understaffed), so we started our apps and drinks at a 4-top table at the bar, which was fine.  --Foie gras cotton candy - my brother's favorite / must-have item, which they used to have at Bazaar in LA, prior to the California foie gras ban. I love foie gras, and I love cotton candy, but this item was just too strange for me. It wasn't bad, I just couldn't really wrap my head around what it was or what it was supposed to be.  --Classic tartare - really great herby flavor and high quality meat. Huge portion size for an appetizer. Comes served on a giant heavy marble tiered plate - the waitstaff must have very strong forearms!  --Can't remember what it was called, some kind of octopus - perfectly cooked and not chewy, with a delicious sensation of char that lingers   --Brussels sprouts - I remember these being good, but don't really remember the details of what it tasted like  --Smoke & ice fresh oysters - SO smoky, strange, and addictively delicious. Kind of confusing - the menu states that it's a "half dozen..kushi" oysters. We asked to confirm, and the waiter said they were actually kumamoto oysters that evening, which was fine with us. When the order arrived, there were 5 orders, and we asked "wasn't it supposed to be a half dozen?" and he said that's how they come. .. what?  --Braised lamb neck - so tender, so flavorful, so rich, and not at all gamey. You don't even need a knife.   Our server, Sunday (sp?), was really friendly and helpful.   This is a really great restaurant and I will definitely be coming back for special occasions and date nights in the future.   The only few things that will probably prevent me from giving this 5 stars in the future.. 1. half a dozen means 6, not 5, so it's really disappointing when something comes out with fewer items than you were expecting. I would probably still pay the same amount for 5 oysters, but if you say half a dozen, serve half a dozen.  2. a lot of the menu items are borrowed from Jose Andres' other restaurants (and I don't just mean the Bazaar in LA). For example, the croquetas de pollo are also served at Jaleo at the Cosmo. The Pa Amb Tomaquet at Bazaar meat is exactly the same as the Pan de Cristal con Tomate at Jaleo as well. I'm sure if I look more carefully I will find more overlap. The salt air margarita is also found at China Poblano. Though these two particular dishes are, admittedly, two of my go-tos at Jaleo, I think this is just plain lazy!

VM2KAeHlp-i62KO8iaPP7A.text: Had the 10 desserts chosen by the chef for $25. We were given 3 tarts, 3 truffles, and 3 cream puffs. 2 of the cream puffs were filled with chocolate. I was under the impression by the waitress that we were having 10 completely different desserts.   I didn't end up taking a second bite of any of the desserts. They weren't bad but nothing pleased my palette.   The cream puffs were dry and cream filling uninteresting. I don't remember the truffles other than the earl grey which was the best out of the 3. None of the tarts worked for me. I liked the passion fruit tart until I got to the banana strawberry tasting yogurt at the bottom. If it was filled with just passion fruit I would have liked it. Chocolate raspberry tart needed less raspberry and more chocolate. The dessert sampler is a good idea because of the variety it offers but each individual dessert is not good on it's own.   The presentation of the desserts far exceeded the taste of the desserts.

I can go on and on, but do yourself a favor and just go!!  SLS needs more people in there it's DEAD!!

xDpXNlaIrH-YmHZg757L_w.text: Great restaurant and easy peazy reservations over the phone at SLS. I went with a buddy for a chefs out dinner and we did the summer tasting menu. 65$ with lots of chow. Add wine for 25$ cdn.slslasvegas.com/db/c... The wines were solid if a little lackluster and the server didn't tell us about the menu we had to ask. He also showed us the other tasting menus that had "value" for 150$ and 200$ a person. His definition of "value" goes in his pocket with a tip. Ha! Anyways there was plenty of great grub centered around an entree of roasted filet, robuchon potatoes,and grilled asparagus with romesco sauce. Probably the most fun thing to east was the giant chicharon and yogurt mousse with sumac. We got to break it to bits with a mallet! I'm not gonna let the initial attitude from the server weigh me down. He warmed up after a bit and we didn't camp all night at the table. I would recommend simply on this menu.

1B2bX8J_bQsWjNhQ0CIdzw.text: great atmosphere, excellent service, outstanding food! a little on the expensive side, but am glad we tried it out!

YvRNTEXKilP92GataylOAw.text: It's on the strip but not on the main strip.  The restaurant is located inside the SLS hotel and the restaurant is in a dark back corner of the hotel near the hotel's nightclub.  Please be warned that you need an extremely long time blocked out to eat here if you plan on eating a steak.  We were here for dinner for over three hours!  It wasn't the fact that meal took so long but there was an extremely long lull in between some of our small plates and the larger entrees.  So long that it felt awkward!  The food overall was good but not great and I recommend eating at one of the many delicious establishments in Las Vegas.    However, one redeeming quality of Bazaar Meat was the service.  Our service was amazing and charismatic.  He deserves every dollar of that $300+ tip that he received.  The steaks were good but not great (the entire table agreed that Del Frisco was better for steaks).  However, someone at our table did get the rack of lamb and it was probably one of the best rack of lambs that I"ve ever tasted.    Also, if you like traditional oysters, stay away from the smoke and ice oysters.  I didn't think it was tasty at all and I absolutely love oysters.  The presentation was neat and dramatic but not worth the price.

s2OcvTfGMWeZckg_duth5A.text: The service was bad. Our waiter was very attentive at first but then he got a larger table of business men and pretty much much dropped his concern for us completely. We had to ask the busboy about an appetizer that it appears the waiter forgot about and he helped us out instead. At one point I caught the waiter's attention and as he was coming towards me he gestured for me to wait and then went out of his way to help the larger table instead. To add to the trend he took a long time to refill our water. I understand that being a waiter is a tough job and that he stood to make a lot more money at the other table, but when you are paying the prices you are at this place you expect to be treated well, not as an afterthought.  The food is just okay. I like the suckling pig, but I wouldn't recommend it for parties of two. Even the small quarter portion was too much for us. It is just too oily and fatty to eat so much of it.  The other dishes were alright, but nothing special.   Overall, I would not recommend this restaurant. It is a shame because I was really looking forward to eating here, but yeah, save your money and go somewhere else.

jlFiVQQP1b6rr7V_jxNH5w.text: I am going to go out on a limb and say that this is actually one of the few restaurants on the Strip that is NOT overrated. Located inside the SLS Las Vegas, this is a very nice place to wine and dine and impress your guests.  Like the name implies, this is a meat-centric establishment.The very first display is a Japanese Wagyu Beef certification statement that explains the grade of Wagyu used and it's authentication at Bazaar meat. As soon as you start walking towards your table, you will see the magic happening. It's like a live show of meats being cooked constantly in front of you and the various cuts before cooking. Although this place serves more than just steaks, you should really try a cut of something if this is your first time here.  I do recommend trying any one of their salads. The presentation and arrangement of these salads are very unique and of course, very tasty. Additionally with your steak (of which I assume you're having), try the Robuchon potatoes. I'm gonna use the word 'dangerous' when describing this stuff. Also, 'incredible'. The desserts here are the only items that didn't really amaze me but they were still good. The outstanding wine selection will round out your evening.  This place isn't cheap. If you get a full course dinner, you can run your bill up around $200 per person. To help you out, The SLS and this restaurant have a relationship with BMW of Las Vegas, and you can get a $100 coupon at this restaurant from the dealership when you purchase a new BMW. Enjoy your evening here. I don't mind going to the strip for this place.

v8Jw-SEBOkJgI9Qe8F_KQQ.text: Overall a different experience. We didn't get a reservation so we ended up sitting at one of the tables near the bar. There was a very nice ambuance and the staff was great.   We saw the menu beforehand and already knew what to expect in regards to price. We knew what we wanted but didn't expect the preparation of our steak to take 50 minutes. We would've known if we read these reviews first.  Our order consisted of: Bagel and lox - okay (2 bites) Reuben - okay (2-3 bites) Sloppy Joe - I actually really enjoyed it (came with 2 servings) Bison carppacio - okay (5 slices) Chateaubriand steak, 1lb, med-rare - excellent Cauliflower steak - excellent  The dinner came with air bread, which is pretty much air puffed potato chips. If your diet or religious beliefs prevent you from eating pork, you may want the waiter/waitress to find out if they rub any pork fat juice on the steak. My husband noticed our steak had a little bit of a bacon flavor.  Great service, long wait for main entree, pricey appetizers, different experience...

trPuAyBJi9BD8Njc5EyqvA.text: Hands down best STEAK I've ever had. I called in for a reservation at 7:45pm, arrived at 7:30pm and was greeted and seated immediately. Atmosphere is really nice in addition with low lighting. Our server was on point since the moment we sat down. We ordered two beers and started off with some fresh oysters. By far the best oysters I've ever had. Really fresh and ice cold! We ended up ordering about 3 dozen of them! That's how good they were. We also had the Lucia salad and two of the buttered potato puree. I was skeptical about the puree part, but it's definitely the best potatoes I've had. The Lucia salad was also tasty, the freshness and crunch was a breath of fresh air. I definitely recommend. We also had the king crab cocktail. Fresh. Fresh. Fresh. That's all I'll say. I love crab and seafood in general, so I'm always looking for freshness when it comes to seafood. For another side we had the Grilled Asparagus, the grilled flavored mixed with the bedded romesco sauce was a great blend. Last but not least, the Bone-In Strip Loin Grass Fed Angus. MEDIUM RARE. Amazing! The most juiciest tender meat seasoned to perfection. I'm definitely looking to go back soon. I'll be in Vegas in September with some family, hopefully we can get a chance to drop in. At least for the freshest oysters in town! We also got offered desert on the house from the Manager Pano, which by the way was such a great offer. Unfortunately, we were too stuffed from all the oysters and steak, we had to respectfully decline. Without a doubt we'll be back to try it. With great gratitude, the experience and flavors were immaculate in all ways.

UrYmQnaEO7eQXUIcYzkusg.text: I've changed my original four-star review to a one-star review after getting word that this restaurant notified Yelp to get my original review taken down, and after reconsidering my overall experience at this restaurant. On the night in question, we had great service from Natalie, the server-who-used-to-be-a-gymnast. She truly was one of the best servers we've had in ages. However, the food was atrocious. Overpriced and terrible quality--low-grade dog food at best. I wasn't impressed with anything that we ordered. My wife said she felt ill after eating her meat--it was truly low quality. As for the service? It was TERRIBLE before Natalie saved us! We sat at our table for 40 minutes before being served! One of the busboys gave us attitude when we finally asked him to get our server. I wish I'd gotten his name. He was tall with dark hair, fairly well built, with a negative attitude that made me want to teach him a lesson (but he was twice my size and ten times less my intellect, so I refrained). The other servers and busboys could have cared less that we were sitting there unserved for nearly an hour. Natalie was the only good point--she truly tried to make the situation right. Plus we had great entertainment watching a bunch of men from the car wash convention next door romancing a bunch of young women at the table next to ours. The guys all had nice, shiny wedding rings on their fingers and were about 40-50 years old. The women were in their twenties, dressed scantily, and clearly unmarried...take a guess. Like I said, great entertainment but certainly not worth much when the food was so bad. I definitely won't be going back, and I'll be sure to spread the word.

CmBIDbvS2IqC8ejiSLkLYw.text: Service and food are amazing!  Best steakhouse on the strip. We told them that it's my and my hubby's anniversary and gave us desert on the house.. Lovely place!

clHSWFhaUzg1DBQeKRgkrA.text: My boyfriend and I staycationed at the SLS Monday night,  and had an overall lack luster experience. However,  we chose Bazaar for dinner and it was not only the highlight of our night, but one of the better dining experiences we've had. Not only was the food incredible,  but the service was second to none.  Our server Nick was not only devilishly handsome, but incredibly friendly and accommodating.  The sommelier, Lou, is one of the most fascinating people I have spoken with,  and gave us some mind blowing wine recommendations and food pairings. We ended up with a bottle of wine my boyfriend had been searching for for 8 years, and he even knew where we could buy it! We were so thrilled we asked for the GM, Chris, who stopped by and chatted with us for a bit. He was gracious and down to earth,  and gave us a small tasting of a few of their charcuterie options. It was an amazing dining experience,  and I will most definitely be back.

vf9EpgOMo3mcd7sA_BhjOQ.text: I have been to a lot of steakhouses but for sure at 4 stars, this is overrated.    First of all, we arrived 15 minutes before our reservation, the restaurant had a lot of empty tables and we were led to the very back, in a small room at the farthest point of the restaurant.   I thought we were being escorted out of the restaurant.   This was already a bad sign for me and I almost wanted to ask our group to leave but everyone was hungry. We ordered the bread with tomato spread, Kobe beef, a total of 4 lbs of ribeye (the server told us we HAVE TO ORDER A MINIMUM OF 2 POUNDS for EACH ribeye) for the 4 of us, mashed potatoes and baby corn with cheese.      Check out the photo of the steak, does that look like it's 2 pounds?????  And we got 2 of those to make 4 pounds). Everything was just ok, the rib eye steaks were under seasoned and not that tender, the Kobe beef, what??????  I practically blanched it on that hot plate and it was not as tender as I EXPECTED it would be.    The Wagyu beef that I buy from Bristol farms is a lot more tender!   Very disappointed overall.   I would have given 1 1/2 stars for service but that was being too generous.  Would I recommend this restaurant?   Would I come back?  Probably NOT!

TFcotPWkLnmNNO1uQ86Neg.text: This was a good restaurant,  but nothing outstanding.  The food was tasty, and nothing was technically wrong. However, it just didn't leave a lasting impression.  It's kind of like a typical online date:great match on paper, but no chemistry in person.  That's how Jose Andres and I are. *Luckily, I was with my boyfriend, so who cares about Jose.   Pros:  I liked the cocktails. I liked the bar ambiance.  The oysters worked.  I liked that my super handsome date could sit next to me.   Cons: The food came out in a weird order.  We were warned, but it still seemed odd to have to wait for side dishes of a steak.   We were early for our reservation,  but still had to wait. It was off putting, considering there were many empty tables. Also, our table was kind of lonely and far away from the action it seemed (except for the one drunken table directly in front of us).    Overall....a typical Vegas restaurant.

Y336lul1lTbYjsETeUDv4w.text: We had high hopes for our dinner at Bazaar Meat - we read the reviews and have really enjoyed other Jose Andres restaurants in the past. Unfortunately, this meal was the low spot of our trip for the following reasons: - Service was slow/inattentive - we had to ask for water (tap) several times, plus our wine didn't get served on time for our entrees - Pacing of the dishes was off - we had several dishes arriving at once, so it was hard to enjoy everything while it was still hot. This was after we asked about pacing when we ordered. - Terrible wagyu dish - out server said that they braise it for something like 20 hrs. It tasted like overcooked liver. We sent it back.  - Vegetable dishes were under-seasoned and not cooked evenly - The dining room was super hot - we understand that it's an open fire cooking place, but other places like Metropole in Cincinnati do this without make the entire place into an inferno - Our check ended up having the wine from the table next to us on it - it was corrected, but without much apology or concern given that it was a $150 bottle  That said, there were a few great dishes - classic tartare, giant chicharone, and the foie gras cotton candy. While they were quite good, they weren't good enough to balance out the negatives of the meal. It's a shame - we loved Jaleo earlier in the week. We'll just stick with that place from now on - it's consistently exceptional.

2fiIH0VZMAPJT7UocMuwuQ.text: Best food atmosphere and most of all...service! Thx John!! Appreciate u!! When a giant steak isn't what you're looking for...they offer a 16 course sampling option that is filled with fun and amazing tasting foods...ahhhh! I love this place

ZBzHoi_7ygyq8ihmF1Q_Mw.text: Nick has been my waiter the many times I've been to Bazaar Meats, and I'd change my reservation to another date/time to get him every time. He's patient, knows food, knows the 3-8 menus you'll look at while you're there (crazy number of menus!!!), and he'll ensure you have the perfect experience.   Start with the gin & tonic. I'm not even a gin & tonic gal and it's one of my favorite drinks of all time, but only from Bazaar Meats. Start there and then find the right wine pairings for your meal. There is a page of wine by the glass to choose from, not a ton, but if you're the only one wanting wine all you need is a glass or two. Let's be real - you'll need red wine to go with your meats.   Automatically order the cotton candy foie gras when you order your drinks. It's like a bite of sweet whimsical butter. Your tastebuds will be inspired. Then you've got time to be walked through the menu with your senses engaged.   Don't even peruse the menu(s) until your waiter walks you through them. It's overwhelming. If you're a first timer - start with a tasting menu. They normally have 3 tasting menus at $150, $200, or $275. The $200 is my go-to, main difference between that one and the $275 is the sucking pig.   I forget what it's called but there is a table side sorbet you should get as a palette cleanser. It has booze in it, if I'm remembering correctly. Either way - this is more of a bonus than a must have.   These are my favorite items I've had: the croquettes de pollo, the carpaccio with Parmesan, the caviar flight, the cold smoked oysters, Chateaubriand, sucking pig, grilled pulpo (octopus), classic tartare, geoduck.   I won't go through all the veggies, but they're all good. You must order their mashed potatoes, as in must. Did I mention must. Go ahead and get 2 orders if you've got more than 3 hungry people.   Desserts - yes please. Just get whatever you're feeling and you'll be happy.   My least favorite orders are few, but they weren't worth the ordering in my experience. The chicharron was a giant mess of fried pig skin. It gets everywhere and is forgettable. The other disappointment was the Lindsay Ranch. It's pricey and the flavor was mild. For $95/lb there are better items on the menu.   I feel like I always end describing the decor. It's the fat kid in me. I love the feel and appeal of Bazaar Meats. It's a mix between somehow glitzy random as hell and a hunting expedition. You'll see.

photos.caption: Photo of Bazaar Meat by José Andrés - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Grilled pulpo (octopus)! Very good.
Photo of Bazaar Meat by José Andrés - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Table side classic tartar
Photo of Bazaar Meat by José Andrés - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Cotton candy foie gras - order it when you order your drinks to start.

QaeLo8BM3qIaXV9UV0LmVA.text: I love Jose Andres but perhaps my expectations were just a bit too high.  Bazaar Meats emphasizes their massive cuts of meat and 3 pound ribeyes, but Jaleo does many of the same or similar sides and apps better. I'd go back to Jaleo for better versions of everything except the meat dishes. Come hungry and leave the vegetarians at home.  DRINKS Jose's G&T is always a good start, but the LN2 (more like an alcoholic sorbet than a drink) comes with fun tableside presentation. Did not care for Jose's Vespa or the Hemmingway.  STARTERS & SIDES Ferran Adria Olives, Modern & Traditional: Got these again after loving the concept at Jaleo, but they were not as appreciated by our dining companions *The Classic Tartare: easily one of the best dishes we had, one I would come back for. Made tableside and seasoned to your preference, the beef sirloin comes from retired dairy cows and is supremely flavorful.  Vittore 1950 Carpaccio: accidentally received this after ordering the bison buffalo version, but kept it. A well-done classic with parmesan, croutons, capers, and sherry. I would still like to try the buffalo version eventually. The Lhardy's Madrid Beef (soup): served in a tiny teacup, the consomme, quail egg, sherry, and caviar were underwhelming. Wouldn't get this again, it doesn't really work, and I don't understand why it's on the menu. A simple tomato salad: There is such a thing as being too simple. Three or four cubes of various sweeter tomatoes, plus a light dressing and red onion. I liked the unusual selection of tomatoes but this dish seemed to be missing something.  *S'mores: Homemade graham crackers and marshmallows plus chocolate and foie gras? This was a surprise hit with our more conservative dining partners! Should have asked for this at the end of the meal as it was better than the desserts we had and less fittingly placed as a starter course.  MEATS Merino Lamb Rack, New Zealand: The version at Jaleo is better. This was unevenly seasoned, rendering some of the chops almost bland. The chimmichurri sauce Jaleo's version is plated with would have elevated this dish. *Wagyu Beef Cheeks: Tender and flavorful meat was complemented by the citrus and slightly-spicy mojo rojo, which I wish there was more of (as others have said). Good choice. *Braised Lamb Neck: Perfectly medium-rare lamb, juicy and well seasoned, plus fried oysters and fried potatoes. The oyster catsup was unnecessary because all of the other components were so well done. Recommend!  DESSERT Everything is itty-bitty bite-sized, making our usual habit of sharing dessert difficult. The tiramisu creme puff disappointed the person who chose it, while the raspberry yuzu tart was interesting and fun. By far the favorite was the sea salt caramel crisp.   Service was friendly and informative, if a touch too casual. The tableside presentation was fun, and the guy who worked with us was personable. Note that there are three (great-sounding) tiered tasting menus, from $150/pp to $275, this information is not present on the website.  Part of having the best experience here is going with the right group of people, and unfortunately the couple we dined with didn't seem to enjoy many of the items. My rating is rounded up to 4 stars from what is more accurately 3.5, as that is partially my fault. Less than half of our dishes (admittedly mostly classic options) were wonderful, while the other half was disappointing. I'll come back to split a steak with my guy (and try the cotton candy foie!), but I'm not in a rush to do so.

KsQt0Bt1RBcW5KPfyZdxTg.text: Might be my favorite restaurant in Las Vegas right now.  Super unique experience. I compared the feeling I felt, walking in to the first time I walked into a multi-course preset meal. I have been telling my friends that I was brought, back to the first time I dined at the French Laundry, or Masa, and Nobu.   I tingled.  The food was excellent, and, was very unique. Steakhouse + Tapas = Bazaar Meat. I'm not sure how else to describe it. Even though it's labelled as such, it didn't quite make sense until our meal started unfolding in front of us, like a really good book.  I fell in love with everything that was set in front of us. Highlights include the Cold Smoked Oysters, Liquid Olives (thinking about these 2, makes me come, a little), the matured meat (totally different flavor profile) and the play on a black forest dessert. We probably sampled a dozen+ items, all of which were great, at worst.  Unfortunately, I didn't feel like a cocktail when we sat, or with apps like I tend to do, so I feel like I missed out on a little of what my normal dining experience would be. (Well, maybe that's fortunate. It gives me more reason to return.)   I really can not wait to return... This restaurant has made dining in Vegas exciting to me, again. Lifetime bucket list has a new entry, and that is eat more Bazaar Meat.

xi0Mt_1Ul2OqCervgy4hjQ.text: Carnal is the perfect word to describe this impeccable dining experience by Jose Andres. This is an indulgence that is totally worth it. Our server went above and beyond as we enjoyed the tasting menu and celebrated our anniversary. The food is on point but the atmosphere is is what really elevates this meal. The entrance is grand and really sets the tone. One for the books.

V6GnMvezAMqcw3rv20Cvig.text: I was referrals by a friend saying they got certified Wagyu Beef! We made appointment which was quick and easy to be done online! The pros are the piglet that you order in advance, it's good but slightly pricy! But it's okay The Wagyu Beef was what most disapointment, we were recommended to order the Wagyu steak which it was around $350 for a pice of stick as far for the size but it was not A5! I can totally tell the quality of A5! The one he recommended me was American Wagyu which I clearly stated I wanted A5 Wagyu! Failed Most stuffs are good that's why I gave 3 stars!  You could come try it once but not second

BOG5RKAQfyNThfzvM-alpw.text: It was by far one of the best meals I've ever had, made even better by an amazing staff! The croquetas are a must try, Lucia's salad was delicious, the foie gras cotton candy was very unique and we'll executed, the Reuben was surprisingly light and very tasty, they sear the A5 Kobe beef right there next to the table, the buttered potato puree was out of this world, and the "vaca vieja" steak was so well prepared that it blew us away. The desserts were phenomenal, especially the s'mores, bonbon, and yuzu. Misty was our server, and she took very good care of us. She helped with everything from picking our wine, starters, and even our meat choice. Gonna be back again soon for more! Our experience from start to finish was superb: seated right away, even given a choice of tables, the tour was fantastic, all of our menu and wine list questions were answered very well, our water glasses were never empty, and all the staff seemed to be helping each other out. The intimate atmosphere was just that- intimate. It's was relatively quiet, the lighting was dim, but well positioned so we could still read the menu.

Ul2o7_aSLUzNlqM7OFd4Dg.text: The food was good, but WAY overpriced.  Very disappointed overall in the whole restaurant.  Can't recommend this to anyone. So many other steakhouses and Restaurants in Vegas are better than this place.

ABT9diNWM-PXmfqSS-bxQg.text: I've been going to The Bazaar in Beverly Hills for years now. So when we decided to got to Bazaar Meat in Las Vegas we were going in with high expectations. I've always loved the decor of Jose Andres restaurants, the colors and the layout of the spaces makes you want to explore.   Before I got any further, the way the food is ordered at the Meats compared to The Bazaar in BH is totally different. Meats is more like a order appetizers and Entree kinds style vs the BH restaurant it's more Tapa (small plates) style based. Meats does offer some of the same dishes.   The Service: Service was just ok, shortage of water was a problem. We kept asking for water vs. just getting check on by our waiter. We had an early appointment and the food turn around was slower than anticipated.   Food: Was good but for the price I was waiting for the Wow factor.   Conclusion, I'll be going to the Bazaar in Beverly Hills but not Bazaar Meat in Vegas. To bad, I really wanted to love this place.

Ae3-1o9hMv4MsOIOUr_QcQ.text: Hands down, THE best steak that I have ever had and it wasn't even their "top shelf" one...!   For appetizers we had the Cesar salad, (missed the mark but still good). Presentation of it was nice. The Super Giant Pork-skin Chicharron - which was impressive by sight and taste! We had oysters, as well - which the ones fro the PNW were the best, IMO. We had the cured meats that were selected by our waiter and they were amazing, as well.  The greens salad was way better than we had expected and so we ordered an additional one.  Came here with family and we were all incredibly impressed with the food, service and drinks. There were 5 of us and we had the Rosewood cut. Amazingly flavorful. Needed nothing extra to add flavor. Had the Suckling Pig, which is probably my favorite... If there is any meat that you try here... It would have to be this one... There is no description that can really capture it so you just have to try it. You won't be disappointed. Also had the King crab legs - cooked to perfection.  This place is no where cheap or middle of the road. Go for the experience and the taste of the food. It was well worth both! We look forward to coming back again!

NpFGRk_ZF9GPW7A0wk60Nw.text: Just about as good as it gets.  If you love steak and great tapas style food with a playful  modern influence.  This is hands down the world heavy weight champion!  What's so refreshing is the setting, ambiance and approach.  Most steak houses are white table cloth or they try to just look modern but just look unfinished.  What's going on here from when you enter the SLS through the main room to the restaurant is just a larger than life environment.    But how about the main character the food!  If you get the opportunity to have the $200 pp taste of everything... DO IT.  You won't be disappointed.  I can't even count how many rounds of taps, including oysters, cured meats, etc, etc. etc.  But the grand finally two huge steaks Rib-eye and tenderloin that just about melted in my mouth.   I can't really improve upon what's been said or the pics already up, so I won't.  From a guy who frequents many steakhouses and only dines on USDA Prime, this is the spot!  Enjoy.

grCClh-qzYKRhm4MREap8Q.text: What can I say except that Jose Andres is a genius. All of his restaurants offer a unique experience and by far has been one of the best dining experiences I have had. From the moment you walk in you are greeted with the aroma of the open fire grill where the meats are prepared. The decor is eclectic, whimsical but at the same time elegant.  Even the menu was beautiful made of black laquer decorated in a Baroque style. Just by the menu you knew you were in for a unique experience.  Most of the dishes are tapa style which are meant to be shared.  They also offer three different price fix menu started from $150pp to $250pp. Knowing that the dishes were on the small side we opted for the tasting menu. We really wanted to try his best dishes and knew this would be a good choice. We chose the second tier which was really way too much food, but we got to try a little of everything. The list is way to long and everything was exceptional so I will try and highlight our favorite dishes. Our first dish was the super giant pork skin chicharron. This is what I mean by unique. They place the chicharron on top of a piece of parchment paper and place it in the middle of the table and the waiter comes out with a mallet and starts breaking up the giant pork skin chicharron to pieces. Weird huh?  Don't be fooled this is no gimmick this is some serious tasting stuff. The next dish was the caviar flight. Each caviar and condiment was served in a beautiful glass sculpture which was stunning. Instead of serving alongside toast points it was served with puffed potato chips. The creme fraiche was served in a small tube representative of a painters tube. Very appropriate since the display was a work of art. These dishes were all very exciting, but the dish that took my breath away was the smoke and ice oysters and by this point I am suffering from sensory overload. I think there might have been smoke because of the ice used, but I can't recall. All I remember is an explosion of unusual yet delicious flavors, smokiness ,sweetness, and tart. The combination was phenomenal. The other dishes that are must haves are the croquetas which are served inside a paper cone and placed inside of a glass tennis shoe. This is a signature dish which he also serves at his other restaurant Jaleo. The next dish was the grilled Pulpo a la Gallega (Octopus) which was tender and grilled to perfection.  Now for the star of the show which is the steak. Amazing, but by this time we were stuffed. We were definitely way over our heads on this one. There were many more dishes and all were amazing. So a la carte or price fixed menu I don't think you could go wrong.  The restaurant is amazing and a bit pricey, but well worth every penny. It is definitely the ultimate dining experience.

sZVkVbMCv0FuCESb45BtIQ.text: My first thought was to try the tasting menu for $200 or $275, but there were items I wanted that were not offered, so I went for individual items that rated well on Yelp. Thank you fellow Yelpers!!  I started with the foie gras cotton candy (delightful and whimsical). Then I had Robouchon mashed potatoes saturated in butter--divinely decadent!!  And lastly, I had 4 ounces of sliced Kobe ribeye that I got to cook at my table along with mustard greens (had no idea how much I like mustard greens!).  It was delicious.  I'm done with Kobe beef now, however.  It just seems overly fatty to me, personally. I chose 3 bite sized deserts that I no longer remember but were heavenly. It was a wonderful meal albeit $170 just for me without any alcohol.  I wanted to give it 4.5 stars but was stunted by Yelp's whole star system.

Photo of Bazaar Meat by José Andrés - Las Vegas, NV, United States

OvFJ48_7hIsIJm1M1bUO4g.text: I was really looking forward to dining here, but the overall experience fell flat. Maybe we didn't order the right dishes...? But if you're charging premium prices, then everything should taste great. That or perhaps the waitress could have suggested some other food items...?   Tableside Cocktail (don't have the exact description but it had lemon and grapefruit flavors) --- It was cool to see this made, but the cocktail was very small (even though she made a huge batch of extras, but didn't serve it) and it was very bitter from the grapefruit.   Lucia's Salad: Endive Caesar salad, Parmesan, anchovy, air croutons ($15) --- I can't believe this item is on the menu. This was their take on a "Caesar salad", but seriously... don't charge $15 for 6 little nothings! See photo!  Vittore 1950: Tenderloin of beef, black pepper, Parmesan cheese, capers, croutons, Sherry dressing ($24) --- This was fantastic, would highly recommend it. One of the best carpaccio I've ever had.  Cotton Candy Foie Gras: Crispy amaranth ($8 each) --- Really enjoyed this. You have to put the whole thing in your mouth at once... the fois gras piece just melts in your mouth.   Cauliflower Steak: Pine nuts, preserved lemon ($15) --- I love cauliflower, but this was probably the worst I've had other than eating it raw... Just tasted burnt... didn't taste the pine nuts or much of the lemon.  Brussels Sprouts Petals: Apricots, grapes, lemon air, lemon puree ($15) --- Tasted okay... wasn't particularly impressed and wasn't all that flavourful. Doesn't help that the portion size is small.  Washugyu/Angus (Lindsay Ranch, OR) ($98/lb) --- Ours was around 2.5 lbs? But when it came out there wasn't as much meat... probably mostly bone. The steak was a letdown... Considering it cost us over $200, this should have tasted like butter and super flavorful. It was tender, but lacked flavor overall. None of us were fighting to have the last few pieces, and we were left hungry...  Just to compare, we had a 24oz rib-eye steak at Sugarcane Raw Bar Grill @ The Venetian and THAT steak was A-MAZING, had more meat despite being less lbs and was also cheaper ($95 total with toppings and a side). So I'm not trying to be a steak snob by shooting this one down.  Dessert Cart (don't have prices) --- This looked beautiful when they brought it over. Had a praline pastry inspired by Pierre Herme, chocolate eclair, tart, tiramisu cream puffs (no photo). Overall they were good.  Overall Service = okay. Didn't provide much recommendations other than explaining how to order the steaks... which in the end wasn't great.  Overall Ambience = It's okay. I love looking at the steak counter, but didn't help the steak wasn't great.   Location = SLS Hotel... took an Uber to get here, so it's a bit of a trek up north along the Strip. The hotel is newer, but not very happening...
